thread.title: US Economy Adds 215,000 New Jobs In July
thread.title_full: US Economy Adds 215,000 New Jobs In July

title: US Economy Adds 215,000 New Jobs In July
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Fri, Aug 7, 2015, 18:03 BST - UK Markets closed US Economy Adds 215,000 New Jobs In July By (c) Sky News 2015 | Sky News – 2 hours 30 minutes ago 

Construction employment rebounded in July increasing the likelihood of an interest rate rise in September. 
The US economy added 215,000 new jobs in July whilst wages rose 0.2% following a surprise stall in June. 
This prompted a 0.2% rally in the US dollar versus the pound as traders predict that an interest rate rise in September is now more likely. 
Though the rate of hiring was slower than July last year, it remains well in excess of the rate required to keep up with population growth. 
Earnings growth was also strong, meaning that average pay packets are now 2.1% higher than they were last year. 
Initial economist estimates had ranged from 210,000 to 262,000, so the actual figure was closer to the bottom of the range, and although wage growth had previously been weak the increase in minimum wage in several states is being reflected in today's data which show that average hourly earnings rose 5 cents, equivalent to a 0.2% rise. 
The world's largest private sector employer, Walmart, has increased pay for hourly workers and this is believed to have bolstered average earnings across the country. 
The overall unemployment rate remained unchanged at 5.3%. 
Markit economist, Chris Williamson, commenting on the data said: "today’s report does nothing to discourage the belief that a September hike is very much on the table, albeit by no means a done deal". 
Much like the Bank of England any rate rises by the Fed are likely to be very modest, especially given the strength of the US dollar which has risen by nearly 19% against the Euro in the last 12 months. 
Chris Williamson also highlighted a reduction in commodity prices as potential excuse for delaying a rate rise: "Oil and other commodities have meanwhile seen renewed falls in recent months, and slumping emerging market growth suggests they could remain low by historical standards, reducing the Fed’s inflation projections."
